content: Tutorial of Leetcode #175 Combine Two Tables
title: Leetcode Easy #175: Combine Two Tables

content: A humble tutorial for Leetcode challenge #175 Combine Two Tables. Note This tutorial is based on MySQL. The author had referred several answer from Leetcode community and improvised into this suggested answer.
title: Leetcode Easy #175: Combine Two Tables

content: 1 Problem: Reverse Integer Write a SQL query for a report that provides the following information for each person in the Person table, regardless if there is an address for each of those people: FirstName, LastName, City, State Table Schema: Person Column Name Type PersonId int FirstName varchar LastName varchar PersonId is the primary key column for this table. Table Schema: Address Column Name Type AddressId int PersonId int City varchar State varchar AddressId is the primary key column for this table.
title: Leetcode Easy #175: Combine Two Tables

content: 2 Technical Analysis
title: Leetcode Easy #175: Combine Two Tables

content: 2.1 Neccesary Columns Name necessary column from two tables. Solution: Basic SQL SELECT Use SELECT to include all necesary column from two table. select a.FirstName,a.LastName from Person a; select b.City,b.State from Address b; Expected Output FirstName LastName Allen Wang
title: Leetcode Easy #175: Combine Two Tables

content: 2.2 Combine Two Tables We need to combine these two table into one. Solution: SQL LEFT JOIN Use LEFT JOIN … ON to combine the tables. Make sure same unique key of the tables. select a.FirstName,a.LastName,b.City,b.State from Person a left join Address b on a.PersonId = b.PersonId Expected Output FirstName LastName City State Allen Wang null null
title: Leetcode Easy #175: Combine Two Tables

content: 3 Test Bench select a.FirstName,a.LastName,b.City,b.State from Person a left join Address b on a.PersonId = b.PersonId Result FirstName LastName City State Allen Wang null null
title: Leetcode Easy #175: Combine Two Tables

content: Tutorial of Leetcode #7 Reverse Integer
title: Leetcode Easy #7: Reverse Integer

content: A humble tutorial for Leetcode challenge #7 Reverse Integer. Note This tutorial is based on Python 3. The author had referred several answer from Leetcode community and improvised into this suggested answer.
title: Leetcode Easy #7: Reverse Integer

content: 1 Problem: Reverse Integer Given a signed 32-bit integer x, return x with its digits reversed. If reversing x causes the value to go outside the signed 32-bit integer range $ -2^{31} \le y \le 2^{31} - 1 $, then return 0. Assume the environment does not allow you to store 64-bit integers (signed or unsigned) Example Scenario Input Output #1 123 321 #2 -123 -321 #3 120 21 #4 0 0
title: Leetcode Easy #7: Reverse Integer

content: 2 Technical Analysis
title: Leetcode Easy #7: Reverse Integer

content: 2.1 Integer Sign We need to determine the input interger sign and expect the output with the same sign. Solution: Determine sign of interger by math logic First determine the integer sign by comparing input to 0 (zero). Expected output is a Boolean type. Then use Boolean type data as integer, True == 1 & False == 0, to identify the sign x = -203 s = (x > 0) - (x < 0) print('The sign of input is {}'.format(s)) Expected Output The sign of input is -1
title: Leetcode Easy #7: Reverse Integer

content: 2.2 Reverse Integer Numbers in the integer need to be reversed. Solution: Convert integer to string type and reverse using slicing Convert input integer to sign-less integer. Cast sign-less input to string type. Use slice string to reverse. Slice rule [ start : end : step ]. Cast string type reversed sign-less data back to integer. x = -203 s = (x > 0) - (x < 0) r = int(str(x*s)[::-1]) print('The reversed input is {}'.format(r)) Expected Output The reversed input is 302
title: Leetcode Easy #7: Reverse Integer

content: 2.3 Contraint The challenge’s contraint is the reversed integer value must be within the range of $$ -2^{31} \le y \le 2^{31} - 1 $$ Solution: Multiply signed reversed integer with boolean value State the constraint above. Multiply boolean result of the contraint to sign and reversed integer. x = -203 s = (x > 0) - (x < 0) r = int(str(x*s)[::-1]) c = (r >= (-(2**31))) and (r <= ((2**31)-1)) z = s * r * c print('The reverse intger is {}'.format(z)) Expected Output The reverse intger is -302
title: Leetcode Easy #7: Reverse Integer

content: 3 Test Bench class Solution(object): def reverse(self, x): s = (x > 0) - (x < 0) r = int(str(x*s)[::-1]) c = (r >= (-(2**31))) and (r <= ((2**31)-1)) y = s*r*c return y input = -203 Solution().reverse(input) Result CPU times: user 2 µs, sys: 1 µs, total: 3 µs Wall time: 4.77 µs -302
title: Leetcode Easy #7: Reverse Integer

content: Tutorial of Leetcode #1 Two Sum
title: Leetcode Easy #1: Two Sum

content: A humble tutorial for Leetcode challenge #1 Two Sum. Note This tutorial is based on Python 3. The author had referred several answer from Leetcode community and improvised into this suggested answer.
title: Leetcode Easy #1: Two Sum

content: 1 Problem: Two Sum Given an array of integers nums and an integer target, return indices of the two numbers such that they add up to target. You may assume that each input would have exactly one solution, and you may not use the same element twice. You can return the answer in any order. Example Scenario Input Target Output #1 [ 2,7,11,15 ] 9 [ 0,1 ] #2 [ 3,2,4 ] 6 [ 1,2 ] #3 [ 3,3 ] 6 [ 0,1 ]
title: Leetcode Easy #1: Two Sum

content: 2 Technical Analysis
title: Leetcode Easy #1: Two Sum

content: 2.1 Determine every target integer and integers after it in input list We need to determine every integer in input list and the other integers after the target integer Solution: Using nested for loop Outer loop: Cycle through the integer in the input list, from first element to the last. Inner loop: Cycle through the integer after the integer from the outer loop nums = [1,0,0,2,9] target = 3 for i in range(len(nums)): for j in range(i+1,len(nums)): print('Outer loop: {0}, Inner loop: {1}'.format(i,j)) Expected Output Outer loop: 0, Inner loop: 1 Outer loop: 0, Inner loop: 2 Outer loop: 0, Inner loop: 3 Outer loop: 0, Inner loop: 4 Outer loop: 1, Inner loop: 2 Outer loop: 1, Inner loop: 3 Outer loop: 1, Inner loop: 4 Outer loop: 2, Inner loop: 3 Outer loop: 2, Inner loop: 4 Outer loop: 3, Inner loop: 4
title: Leetcode Easy #1: Two Sum

content: 2.2 Summation of Integer Pair Integer from outer and inner loop need to be summed and match to the target integer. Solution: Summation of integer pair and check with the target integer Sum the integer from outer and inner loop. Compare with target integer. Return integer pair indices. nums = [1,0,0,2,9] target = 3 for i in range(len(nums)): for j in range(i+1,len(nums)): if nums[i] + nums[j] == target: print('The integer pair indices: {}'.format([i,j])) Expected Output The integer pair indices: [0, 3]
title: Leetcode Easy #1: Two Sum

content: 3 Test Bench class Solution(object): def twoSum(self, nums, target): for i in range(len(nums)): for j in range(i+1,len(nums)): if nums[i] + nums[j] == target: return [i, j] nums = [1,0,0,2,9] target = 3 Solution().twoSum(nums, target) Result CPU times: user 2 µs, sys: 0 ns, total: 2 µs Wall time: 4.77 µs [0, 3]
title: Leetcode Easy #1: Two Sum

content: This article shows the basic Ubuntu Installation.
title: A Guide to Ubuntu Installation & Setup

content: This article offers steps of Linux Ubuntu installation. Note This guide is based on Linux Ubuntu 20.04 LTS. However, the installation steps are similar across other version of Ubuntu. For developers, a robust and versatile operating system (OS) is important. Apple MacOS is good but you need a Macintosh, sometimes it can be over your budget. Windows is excellence for media consumption and office work but setting it up for a proper development purpose outside of Microsoft application may be challenging. Ubuntu is an Linux distribution based on Debian. It is an open-source OS that can run on many modern System-on-Chips (SoC). Some of the key benefits are: It is free! Works on Windows running machine. Dual-boot. Install side-by-side with your Windows OS on a single drive. Huge community support. Excellent developement environment.
title: A Guide to Ubuntu Installation & Setup

content: 1 Prepare Ubuntu bootable USB Ubuntu bootable USB is a portable Ubuntu OS installed on a USB drive. With the bootable USB. You are able to try the Ubuntu desktop experience and install it.
title: A Guide to Ubuntu Installation & Setup

content: 1.1 Download the Ubuntu ISO & Etcher Ubuntu is distributed through the official website. The best Ubuntu image is stable Long-Term-Support (LTS) version. It usually is the first choice on the page. Download latest Ubuntu Desktop image here. Etcher is a free and open-source software for writing image file into storage media to create bootable USB drive or SD cards. It is available for Windows, macOS and Linux. Download latest Etcher here.
title: A Guide to Ubuntu Installation & Setup

content: 1.2 Create Ubuntu bootable USB Etcher offers a simple GUI with 3 buttons. Etcher GUI 3 steps to flash Ubuntu in your USB drive: Click Flash from file and select Ubuntu image file on the left. Select target USB drive you wish to flash on. Click Flash!. The process may take a few minutes. Congratulation! You completed first milestone! Now you have your Ubuntu USB drive and ready to install !
title: A Guide to Ubuntu Installation & Setup

content: 2 Pre Installation
title: A Guide to Ubuntu Installation & Setup

content: 2.1 Physical Drive setup for Ubuntu OS The dilemma is, many of our computer comes with Windows OS pre-installed. It is a bit tricky when we want to use Ubuntu for development on the same machine. We have 3 options: Buy a new HDD/SSD for Ubuntu and replace the Windows drive. Buy a new HDD/SSD for Ubuntu connect the drive in different SATA/NVME slot, if your machine can support more than 1 drive. Install Ubuntu on the same physical drive with Windows OS. If your plan is first option, you can skip to section 2.2. If you plan is second or third option, you are making your Ubuntu Dual-Boot in your machine. Please follow the note below. For Dual Boot: Ubuntu on separated drive Physically disconnect all drives in your machine before you proceed with installation, except the SSD/HDD you wish to install Ubuntu. This is to make sure the Ubuntu GRUB (boot loader) is installed in the same drive with Ubuntu OS. For Dual Boot: Windows-Ubuntu on single drive Assumed you have typical Windows setup, main OS installed on C: volume and D: volume as storage. You may shrink either C: or D: volums depending on your use case. Use Windows’s Disk Management to re-structure disk volume: Press Windows key + x and select Disk Management from the list. Right click the volume you wish to shrink and select Shrink Volume. Enter the amount of space and click Shrink to execute. Now you can see a new unused volume beside the volume you have shrinked. Next step is to install Ubuntu OS on the volume.
title: A Guide to Ubuntu Installation & Setup

content: 2.2 Change boot order of your machine Every computer will have a boot order setting in the BIOS/UEFI. If the computer has multiple bootable drive attached, the first drive in the boot order will be booted. Move the Ubuntu bootable USB drive to the top of the boot order to ensure your computer will boot into that USB drive. Tip Make sure your Ubuntu bootable USB is plugged into USB port before the computer booting-up. If you cannot find the Ubuntu USB in boot order, please restart your computer. To get maximum speed during installation, you are advised to avoid connect the bootable drive to USB port extension. For the best result, please consider on-board USB 3.x port. Different OEM laptop or motherboard may have different trigger to boot in BIOS/UEFI. The trigger key usually is Del or F2. Upon the boot screen appears on your computer screen, hit the trigger key. Restart your machine if you missed it. Boot Screen Example Successful trigger will bring you to BIOS/UEFI menu. Navigate to page contains Boot option. The page will shows the current Boot Option order to the corresponding drives. Change the Boot Order #1 to the Ubuntu bootable USB. Save the current setup at the last page of BIOS/UEFI menu and exit. Your machine will reboot. Boot Order Example
title: A Guide to Ubuntu Installation & Setup

content: 3 Start to install Ubuntu The machine booted in Ubuntu bootable USB will show a BIOS-like black screen with few options. For first time Ubuntu user, you are encourage to select Try Ubuntu without installing and get the first taste of Ubuntu. The option will bring you to a standard Ubuntu Interface with some basic function. In fact, you may also able install Ubuntu OS to your machine in this option. Ubuntu USB Boot Screen In the GUI, you may see the Intall Ubuntu 20.04 LTS (The version number will vary based on the version you are installing). Double click the desktop icon and you will be able to install the OS to your machine. GUI in Try Ubuntu So you have clicked Install Ubuntu 20.04 LTS and you will see a windows pops out and prompt you to choose the language. You can choose any language you comfortable with. After the language, you have to select apps installation options. For normal development, I suggest you follow the the Installation Tips #1 below. Tip For NVIDIA CUDA development , please untick Install third party software for graphic… box. To avoid NVIDIA CUDA issue, we have to install graphic driver separately after the OS installation. Installation Tips #1
title: A Guide to Ubuntu Installation & Setup

content: 3.1 Disk Partition In the page Installation type, you will need to partition your drive for Ubuntu OS. Please select Something else and continue. The table is the guideline for partition. You may change the Size accoridng to your needs. Partition Size(MB) Type Location Use as Mount point EFI 500 Primary Begining of this space EFI System Partition N/A SWAP Double of your RAM size Logical End of this space swap area N/A OS Remaining space Primary Begining of this space Ext4 journaling file system / Installation Tips #2 Select the free space and create partitions by New Partition Table for each particular purpose stated in the table. It is recommended to select Format option for OS partition. Installation Tips #3 After finished partitioning the drive, you can now select the main Device, in this case /dev/sda to Install Now Installation Tips #4 Ubuntu OS installer will warn you about the changes in partition table you have selected. Make sure you selected the correct drive to install Ubuntu then Continue.
title: A Guide to Ubuntu Installation & Setup

content: 3.2 Timezone & Account You have completed the hardest part of the installation! Now you can select your Timezone and your Username & Password.
title: A Guide to Ubuntu Installation & Setup

content: 3.3 Finishing Up Now you can sit back and have a cup of coffee while your Ubuntu is brewing. Installation Finished Please select Restart Now when Ubuntu OS installer told you so. Tip The machine will ask you to remove the Ubuntu bootable USB before it reboot. Do it and hit Enter
title: A Guide to Ubuntu Installation & Setup

content: 4 Post Installation Ta Daa!! Now you should see your Ubuntu welcome screen. Your dev life start by clicking on your username ! Now, once you log in the first time, Ubuntu will ask you several setup. For example, Connect Online Accounts, Livepatch and Help improve Ubuntu. You may do it to suit your case. Personally I will say No to all. A little Extra To update any installed packages sudo apt update sudo apt upgrade
title: A Guide to Ubuntu Installation & Setup
